dt: {bc}to deprive of shelter, protection, or care {bc}subject to risk from a harmful action or condition

dt.t: has not yet been {it}exposed{/it} to measles

dt: {bc}to submit or make accessible to a particular action or influence
{bc}to subject (a sensitive photographic film, plate, or paper) to radiant energy
{bc}to abandon (an infant) especially by leaving in the open
{bc}to disclose the faults or crimes of
{bc}to cause to be visible or open to view {bc}{sx|display||}: such as
{bc}to reveal the face of (a playing card) or the cards of (a player's hand)

pt: {sc}show{/sc} {sc}exhibit{/sc} {sc}display{/sc} {sc}expose{/sc} {sc}parade{/sc} {sc}flaunt{/sc} mean to present so as to invite notice or attention. {sc}show{/sc} implies no more than enabling another to see or examine.

pt.t: {it}showed{/it} her snapshots to the whole group

pt: {sc}exhibit{/sc} stresses putting forward prominently or openly.
{sc}display{/sc} emphasizes putting in a position where others may see to advantage.
{sc}expose{/sc} suggests bringing forth from concealment and displaying.

pt.t: sought to {it}expose{/it} the hypocrisy of the town fathers

pt: {sc}parade{/sc} implies an ostentatious or arrogant displaying.

pt.t: {it}parading{/it} their piety for all to see

pt: {sc}flaunt{/sc} suggests a shameless, boastful, often offensive parading.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}exposer{/it}, from Latin {it}exponere{/it} to set forth, explain (perfect indicative {it}exposui{/it}), from {it}ex-{/it} + {it}ponere{/it} to put, place {ma}{mat|position|}{/ma}
shortdef: to deprive of shelter, protection, or care : subject to risk from a harmful action or condition
to submit or make accessible to a particular action or influence; especially : to subject (a sensitive photographic film, plate, or paper) to radiant energy
to abandon (an infant) especially by leaving in the open

dt: {bc}to show one's sexual organs in public

dt.t: He was arrested for {it}exposing himself{/it} (to women) in the park.

shortdef: to show one's sexual organs in public

dt.t: Workers simply pushed clean sand over other sections of blackened beach; by August, the tides had {wi}reexposed{/wi} the oil.
When the mice were exposed to the bee venom and then {wi}reexposed{/wi} three weeks later at least 80 percent survived …

utxt.t: In refugee situations where women and children's health conditions have improved, repatriation may mean {wi}reexposure{/wi} to diseases and other conditions that will once again throw their lives in jeopardy.
